story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.‘Emergency disease outbreak will often be adequate justification for taking exceptional measures,’ MPs sayEnhanced measures to curb the coronavirus&nbspoutbreak will “significantly curtail” fundamental freedoms in Britain – but can be legally justified, MPs have said.Parliament’s Joint Committee on Human Rights&nbspsaid it would be thoroughly scrutinising new laws and action taken by authorities.“Some measures could significantly curtail inidual rights,” MPs wrote in a briefing paper issued on Thursday.Sharing the full story, not just the headlines“There are other practical and economic impacts on iniduals who cannot work due to self-isolating, or due to sickness – some of these measures will affect certain groups more significantly than others. &nbspHow to be productive if you have to work from home during coronavirusWhich countries around the world has coronavirus spread to?The dirty truth about washing your handsShould you be taking paracetamol or ibuprofen to treat coronavirus?What are symptoms of coronavirus – and where has it spread?It came as the government formally announced details of an Emergency Coronavirus Bill setting out measures aimed at slowing the spread and supporting the NHS and workers.Police have already been given new powers to detain anyone with suspected symptoms and force them to undergo testing or be quarantined, although senior officers insisted they would “not be used willy nilly”.Amid rumours of a nationwide “lockdown”, Gavin Williamson, the education secretary, said the government was ready to take “incredibly tough decisions” but had no immediate plans to shut down restaurants or force people off the streets.The Joint Committee on Human Rights said any action must comply with both international law and the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) but added: “An emergency disease outbreak will often be an adequate justification for taking exceptional measures provided that such measures are justified and proportionate in the circumstances.”No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. The government needs to protect the right to life and at the same time consider the impact on human rights as it strives to protect the country in this unprecedented time.”The committee said quarantine and self-isolation had an impact on the right to liberty and right to life, while a potential ban on public gatherings affected freedom of assembly and association, and school closures hit the right to education.Restricting people’s ability to work has a “disproportionate impact” on the self-employed and other groups, while the impact on small businesses engages the “right to peaceful enjoyment of one’s possessions”.The committee said that any future moves to prioritise or ration healthcare must be “justifiable and non-discriminatory”, and that the prevention of timely funerals could violate freedom of religion.Members said the government must consider the wellbeing of people held in prisons, immigration detention centres and mental health units, as well as the right to&nbspjustice – after new trials of more than three days were stopped.The committee warned that homeless people and those in temporary accommodation will find it difficult to comply with any formal instruction to self-isolate.It called for evidence to be submitted on the steps taken to ensure the government’s plans comply with human rights and to address the impact on groups that will be title: eu nationals settlement scheme home office settled status brexit
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Home Office refuses people EU&nbspsettled status on grounds of&nbspeligibility&nbspfor first timeHundreds of EU nationals have been told they don’t have the right to stay in the UK after applying for post-Brexit immigration status, figures show.The latest statistics on the government’s EU settlement scheme, published on Thursday, show 300 people have been refused settled status. These iniduals will not have a right to live in Britain after the deadline of June 2021, unless they successfully appeal the decision.The number remains proportionately small, as there have been nearly 3 million applications processed overall, but it marks a considerable jump from the previous monthly figures, when just seven people had been refused.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesAt that point the refusals were all on the grounds of criminality, but most of the latest refusals were due to issues around eligibility –&nbspusually because the applicant has been unable to provide the relevant&nbspdocumentary&nbspevidence.While the number is still proportionately low, campaigners have raised alarm at the sudden increase, and it is likely to prompt concern around difficulties more vulnerable people face when obtaining evidence.Charity helping children in care stay in UK has to stop taking casesEU settlement scheme delays leave people unable to get jobsNine out of 10 EU settlement scheme appeals successful, data showsWithout physical proof of our status, EU citizens like me live in fearThe Home Office said officials had made every attempt to obtain the necessary evidence before refusing applications, and that decisions to refuse were not taken lightly and signed off at a high level.Maike Bohn, co-founder of campaign group&nbspthe3million, told The Independent she was concerned by the fact that while there had been no refusals on eligibility grounds before February 2020, there was now a sharp rise.“This is hard to explain. We urgently need more explanation from the Home Office as to why those cases have been refused,” she said. “It is concerning that as soon as the UK left the EU we see people being refused settled status.”Christopher Desira, immigration solicitor at Seraphus law firm, said there were likely to be more and more refusals beyond criminality grounds, which may worry a lot of people in uncommon family arrangements, which tend to be the most complex applications.&nbspHe also raised alarm over the gaps in free outreach and advice services that are likely to form due to the coronavirus outbreak, which may cause problems for those receiving requests for further information from the Home Office, but not know how to respond, and called on the Home Office to pause any refusals until the emergency is over.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailLiberal Democrat home affairs spokesperson Christine Jardine called on the government to back the Private Members’ Bill she tabled last month that would guarantee the rights of EU citizens in the UK.Home Office presides over 100 data breaches in EU settlement schemeShe said: “EU citizens in the UK have been living under a cloud of uncertainty for far too long. They are our families and friends, our colleagues and carers. They must have the right to stay.&nbspEven before the coronavirus crisis, we were warning that tens of thousands of EU citizens will be left without settled status when the Conservative government’s arbitrary deadline hits next year.“That would leave thousands of people effectively undocumented and at risk of eviction, detention and even deportation. It will be a new Windrush scandal on an even bigger scale.”The Home Office figures show that overall, there have been more than 3.34 million applications to the scheme up to the end of February 2020.Minister for future borders and immigration Kevin Foster said: “EU citizens have made huge contributions to our country. It’s good news over three million have now been granted status and will be able to continue to call the UK home for decades to come.”Tory MP admits EU settlement scheme sometimes 'doesn't work as well as we expect'The department&nbspsaid it had&nbspa wide range of support was&nbspavailable online, over the phone and in person to help EU citizens apply for settled status.Earlier this month, the department announced a further £8m of funding to award 57 charities to help vulnerable EU citizens apply, on top of £9m announced for the same cause last April.However many charities in receipt of the original funding said they had been forced to cut back on their services due to uncertainty as to whether the funding would continue beyond the month of March – accusing the Home Office of leaving the announcement until the “last minute”.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.The organisation encourages postponement of the Games until 2021&nbspUSA Swimming has asked for the Tokyo Olympics to be delayed by one year amid the coronavirus pandemic, the organisation wrote in a letter addressed to the&nbspUS&nbspOlympic &amp Paralympic Committee (USOPC).&nbspTim Hinchey said athletes on the team have struggled to train for the upcoming Games, which are anticipated to start in July 2020.&nbsp“Everyone has experienced unimaginable disruptions, mere months before the Olympic Games, which calls into question the authenticity of a level playing field for all,” Mr&nbspHinchey wrote. “Our athletes are under tremendous pressure, stress and anxiety, and their mental health and wellness should be among the highest priorities.”It was also stated that&nbspthe “right and responsible thing to do is to prioritise everyone’s health and safety” during the global pandemic over participating in the Olympics.&nbspSharing the full story, not just the headlinesA one-year delay was requested by the team for the Olympics to instead happen in July 2021 once the toll of the virus subsides.&nbspThe dirty truth about washing your handsWhat is the difference between Covid-19 and it spread?“There are no perfect answers, and this will not be easy however, it is a solution that provides a concrete path forward and allows all athletes to prepare for a safe and successful Olympic Games in 2021,” he wrote.&nbspThe USOPC said earlier on Friday it had not expressed a preference on postponing the Games or given a deadline&nbspto the&nbspInternational Olympic Committee (IOC) to make a final&nbspdecision.&nbsp“I think we would concur with them that we need more expert advice and information than we have today to make a decision,” Susanne Lyons, USOPC’s board chair, said on a conference call with reporters Friday, according to the Washington Post. “And we don’t have to make a decision. Our Games are not next week or two weeks from now. They’re four months from now. I think a lot may change in that time period. So we are affording the IOC the opportunity to gather that information and expert advice, and at this point in time we do not feel it’s necessary for us to insist that they make a decision.”USA Swimming is a huge draw when watching the Olympic Games given the level their athletes perform at, with former&nbspswimmers including Michael Phelps, who is the most decorated Olympian of all time. So the organisation speaking out against the continuation of the Games comes as&nbspa huge blow for the IOC while it weighs the difficult decision.Jacob Pebley, a swimmer on the 2016 US Olympic‘s team, released a statement about why the Games should be postponed this year.&nbspTeam USA and role models for hundreds of thousands of young athletes, attend Olympic Trialsthe Olympics in good conscience?” he wrote. “To do so would fly in the face of all emerging evidence and best practices for social distancing and protecting the health of vulnerable communities.”US Gymnastics team has not publicly taken a position on if the Olympics should be postponed this year.&nbspThe British Olympic Association (BOA) recently said it would not “endanger the health” of its athletes by encouraging them to train for the Games if it was not in their best interest to do so.&nbsp“We can be categorically clear that we will not endanger the health and wellbeing of the athletes or wider delegation at any point,” the BOA said.&nbsp“It is imperative to preserve competitive integrity for athletes, but it is clearly only wise for athletes to continue to prepare for the Games where it is safe and appropriate to do so, within relevant Government and public health guidelines.”But the organisation said it&nbspstill respected the IOC and its decision-making process when ultimately deciding if the Games should be postponed or continue.&nbspNo hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Chinese city of Wuhan, where the coronavirus&nbspis believed to have&nbsporiginated, remains under lockdown after nearly two months, even as the world’s attention has shifted to other hotspots.These pictures show – through windows and on balconies and rooftops – how Wuhan residents holed up in their apartments are getting on with their lives. People can be seen hanging laundry. Children play. One man eats noodles. Another smokes a cigarette.Chinese officials and some public health experts have credited the draconian confinement measures on a city of 11 million, and much of Hubei province, of which it is the capital, with slowing the spread of the disease and turning the tide of infection across China.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesOther countries, including Iran, Italy and the United States, are struggling to manage their outbreaks.&nbspBut even as the number of new reported cases stops in Wuhan, people in the city remain suspended in an isolated new normal.Residents are forbidden from venturing out of their homes even to buy food, which must be delivered. Schools and most shops remain shut, and roads are virtually empty.&nbspChinese doctors celebrate closure of last coronavirus hospitalScientist whose chilling report convinced Trump of coronavirus threat China ‘set to declare victory over virus’ as Xi makes first Wuhan tripOn Tuesday last week, Wuhan closed the last of 14 makeshift hospitals set up to treat and isolate patients after the outbreak had overwhelmed the city’s healthcare system.&nbspIn a dramatic sign that the situation is improving, president Xi Jinping made a high-profile visit to the stricken city, his first since the outbreak began.Nearly 50,000 coronavirus cases have been reported in Wuhan, with around 2,500 deaths. However, China this week&nbspreported no new domestic cases – meaning the strict isolation measures have been working.&nbspBut the outbreak has also exacted an unquantifiable psychological toll on people in Wuhan as families cope with loss, children are unable to go to school or play outside, and livelihoods are imperilled as people can’t go to work.Reporting by&nbspCarlos Garcia and Tony Munroe, ReutersNo hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Why our 'exceptional' new Chancellor is the bright person for the job
title: bbc sport relief charity finishes
story: The first was to postpone it, like the football and rugby, until such time as the theatre plugs and worthy schemes about “bringing the outside world to pensioners” with breathing dficulties, looked a bit less reckless.The second was to say: “Stuff it, as a one-off gesture to the British public, at this time of crisis, every single penny raised will be spent in Britain.”But Auntie would no more do that than re-run all eight series of Love Thy Neighbour, in The One Show’s slot.So they took option C and just ploughed on regardless, from pm, Friday, with the usual too-many-cooks line-up of Paddy McGuinness, Alex Scott and Gary Lineker, who made this earnest pledge: “We promise we’ll spend tonight’s money with such care on the most vulnerable.”Well, you’d hope so, wouldn’t you. And you’d also hope they take more care than they did with the actual production, which started to betray a “will-this-do ” attitude with almost its first caption of the night.“Dermot Munaghan.” And the next one: “Colston Smith.” .A foretaste of what was to come, because the event had technically unravelled within the first hour when Lineker had to introduce a comedy sketch about VAR and the  World Cup final.First it appeared, then it vanished. So Lineker explained the punchline: VAR had not just found in England’s favour it had decided to award the  World Cup to Scotlandand Euro  to Wales.Then the sketch suddenly reappeared again and took six minutes to reach its bloody, teeth-pulling conclusion: “I’m going to change my name to Jamie VAR-dy.”In such circumstances, you can sit and hope the rest of Sport Relief moves, inspires and thrills with a perfect blend of laughter, compassion and entertainment.And I can also hope Scotland are going to win the next World Cup. It ain’t going to happen.Sport Relief is never ever over quickly, ’cos there are a whole load of BBC formats to be put through the ringer, like Line Of Duty, and far too much dancing, featuring everyone from Lineker and McGuinnes to a “social media influencer”, called “HRVY”, which wasn’t another spelling mistake. I think he’s just an RSHOL.At ious other points in this back-of-a-fag-packet evening: Hockey player Sam Quek took , football penalties against a short fat bloke, from point-blank range, and contrived to miss more than a quarter of them. Mel Giedroyc farted on a Question Of Sport special. Rylan accused Romesh Ranganathan of being over-exposed, before playing Andy Murray at crazy golf. And they flagged up an Action Line number, for people who were feeling “emotionally vulnerable”, after the Killing Steves parody, which may have been the most benevolent gesture in the event’s history.What really irks about Sport Relief, though, is that, evencompassion fatigue has never been more of a problem, they’ve decided it’s a triumph before it’s broadcast and the “Best Bits” Sunday show is all ready to go.Corporate backing also means there’s little risk of them not beating the previous total either, which, I hope, doesn’t sound like I’m diminishing the sincere efforts of the public.If there’s one thing I’ll remember about Sport Relief , however, it’s the contribution of David Beckham, who, infor a y advertorial for his new MLS franchise and some crashing product placement , offered two entire people the chance to attend an Inter Miami game and win a shirt signed by such global talents as Lewis Morgan and A J DeLaGarza, who’s played  entire games for Guam.There are moments when the generosity and humanity of celebrities simply overwhelms me.This wasn’t one of those moments.Bloke.CHANNEL  seemed to have all bases covered for its hugely entertaining new dating show Five Guys A Week, at least in terms of complete bellends.So, crammed into a semi-detached house in St Albans, hoping to win the heart of its owner Amy, it had: Christian, whose job “isn’t as glamorous as it sounds” . Uber-woke Glen, from accounts. A stuntman called Michael, who seemed to have mistaken the show for SAS: Who Dares Wins and voluntarily withdrew on day two. Mad, goggle-eyed surfer Trystan, who appeared to be casing the joint for a “kill room”. And the lowest form of le known to any single thirtysomething man – the bloke with the acoustic guitar, Scott, who used to be a bank manager, but now earns a living as a country and western singer and will be performing under the stage name Johnny Cashpoint,he’s got an ounce of sense.The five were chosen for their ability to get right on the viewers’ nerves rather than real boyfriend potential, obviously.And it made for a cracking hour of TV, because they all competitively fancied the pants off Amy, who looked like a younger and much hotter Camilla Parker Bowles,you can imagine such a thing.The show’s greatest strength, of course, is also its biggest format failing, as I’d imagine no one wanted any of them to win.In the event, however, it came down to a straight fight between the lesser of two evils and, probably wisely, Amy chose cocky Christian, who’s looking to whisk her off for breakfast in France, ahead of grovelling Glen, who, rather than looking for “the Michelle Obama to my Barack”, should probably be aiming for the Michelle Collins to his Ian Beale.Five Guys A Week, C, tonight, .pm.The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “What caused the cancellation of six Wimbledon championships in the s ”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Which city in north-east England shares its common name with the body of a ship ”Spin To Win, Phillip Schofield: “What Saturday night TV show is Anton du Beke most famous for ”Hunted, Dan: “Who painted the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel ”LISA NANDY wasn’t born stupid. She volunteered to be, by standing for Labour Party leader.It means noisily backing every woke cause of the day, until their interests collide, as they did spectacularly on last Tuesday’s Good Morning Britain, where Piers Morgan hit her with two innocuous-sounding questions.“Are babies born either male or female ” and “Would you be happyUsain Bolt and Floyd Mayweather self-identied as women, spent a year having testosterone treatment and competed against women ”Correct answers: Yes and no.But Lisa couldn’t say that for fear of offending either the transgender or feminist lobbies.So instead she blathered, lied, evaded, shouted, demanded an apology from Piers , accused him of laughing and describing transgender people as “grotesque”and at one point muttered: “I don’t know what . . . I don’t know what, well, you know, I don’t know what.”Others would’ve let her off the hook at that point, as she was almost crying at her own stupidity by then. Chunk didn’t.To his eternal credit he ignored two ad breaks and kept up the pressure for a spellbinding  minutes that only ended when Nandy offered to settle the issue of whether Floyd Mayweather should be able to box women by “setting up a commission”.To which Piers responded: “It’s not a commission issue, it’s a common sense issue.”But that, as a wise man once said, is the problem with common sense, Piers. It’s not all that common.Ian Wright: “At this stage, I think three points is three points.”Jamie Redknapp: “Switching off from football is always beneficial sometimes.”Piers Morgan effectively ending Lisa Nandy’s Labour leadership bid on TV’s most consistently entertaining show, Good Morning Britain.Saturday night eye balm from BBC’s Ireland: Edge Of The World. Larry David ending up in the “ugly section” of Tiato’s restaurant, on Curb Your Enthusiasm.Sky’s Breeders managing to make a comedy about children bearable.And John Humphrys’ opening curveball on Saturday’s Celebrity Mastermind: “Name ” “Bez.” “Occupation ” Pass.This Morning, Holly Willoughby: “What should a ‘support neighbour’ look like  ’Cos my mum’s older than me.”Andyour mum isn’t older than you, self-isolate immediately.THIS week’s winner is Future Stewie, from Family Guy, and Chief Medical Officer Professor Chris Whitty.All those self-defined “experts” whose coronavirus response is framed not by their humanity or expertise but the desperate need to be proved right.Every selfish moron in the country being filmed panic-buying toilet rolls.Firebrand left-wing stand-up Guz Khan taking the gig economy advertising shilling from Uber Eats.The comically awful use of Photoshopped throwback pictures in BBC drama The Split.And the never-ending queue of fantasists and egomaniacs at E’s Sex Clinic, like third person-speaking Drew, who announced: “I’m not having vanilla sex. That’s not what the Drew brand is about. Le’s too short, man.” The shorter the better . . . man.The Sex Clinic, Matt: “I think I need to learn to love myself.”Five Guys A Week, Glen: “My talents aren’t obvious. They’re not tangible things.” On account of the fact they don’t exist. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. Why our 'exceptional' new Chancellor is the bright person for the job
title: coronavirus thinking revive blitz spirit
story: People have lost loved ones and will continue to do so, and the virus is going to cause an unprecedented, global economic crisis that could see businesses go under, job losses, and severe financial dficulty for those already living hand to mouth.You’ll no doubt have read the latest bad news.So, solely for the purposes of this article, forgive me , instead, I focus momentarily on trying to find the admittedly few green shoots poking through the rubble.For, unlike Brexitwhich caused bitter ision among communities, the coronavirus pandemicis already bringing communities together that, in the modern age of “smart” devices absorbing our attention, had perhaps become slightly detached from each other in recent years.Professor Steven Taylor, author of The Psychology of Pandemics, says: “People need reminding that they can cope with this. They are resilient. You aren’t going to like it, but you’ll get through it.“You can compare it to the Blitz. People got through the Blitz. It was very stressful but they did it.”My elderly mother lives just a few roads away from me and, like so many with similarly vulnerable relatives, I’m making sure she’s OK.“Just pop a tin of Spam through the letterbox, and I’ll be fine,” she joked in reference to her time growing up during World War Two.But yesterday, three of her immediate neighbours — one of whom she’s never met — put notes through her door to say she should give them a callshe needed anything.In times of such crisis, our first thought is naturally of ourselves and our immediate loved ones.But it seems the upsideof the world slowing down and re-grouping might be that, no longer distracted by the busyness of our normal working days, we will “look up” and “reach out”, as they say in business circles, to those in our communities who might need help.There are plenty of people who already do sterling work in their area, but the onslaught of the coronavirus will perhaps lead to everyone now doing their bit.Quite right too. But the onus can’t solely rest on the shoulders of iniduals, so it’s only right the Government has stepped up to offer some practical help to businesses that will suffer throughout the coming weeks and months.Boris Johnson’s advice that people shouldn’t go to pubs cafes theatres etc is understandable in health terms, but will leave businesses facing a critical downturn in custom through no fault of their own.Yesterday, London restaurateur James Chiaini urged him to “crack open the war chest” and allow local businesses to stay afloat while simultaneously channelling efforts towards helping out in their immediate communities, and it seems that new Chancellor Rishi Sunak has listened.In James’s case, he has staff on hand and lots of food supplies, so instead of shutting down because there are no customers, he and other restaurants across the country could potentially now operate a batch-cooking and delivery service for those in need.Equally, the skill sets of many other businesses can be channelled into providing much-needed, state-funded help where it’s required.And the Government shouldn’t stop there. It should repurpose certain facilities too.Last week, it was reported that the £million Defence Medical Rehabilitation Centre in Loughborough, Leics, is currently seriously underused because only current personnel can access it and only  have done so in the past  months.Madness. At the very least, it should be thrown open to all injured veterans who currently have to go through the overstretched NHS.Or how about temporarily repurposing it as a treatment centre for anyone who could benefit from its facilities, thereby alleviating some of the pressure on local hospitals The Government is clearly in uncharted territory right now because it is dealing with an unprecedented situation.But a continuation of joined-up thinking on how best to get us through this critical phase in our history will ensure that Britain’s enviable “Blitz spirit” is encouraged and kept strong for as long as it needs to be.PRINCE Harry is now back behind the closed doors of his rented Canadian mansion, licking his wounds after his public humiliation at the hands of phone pranksters.During a chat with what he thought was climate change activist Greta Thunberg and her father, Harry pledged his support to the non-existent island of “Chunga-Changa” and failed to question why the hoaxers wanted to ship penguins to the North Pole when they’re actually native to the South Pole.Poor Harry.Still, it perhaps explains why, despite attending Eton, he got D at geography A level.Indeed, on all our faces in these challenging times.Heartfelt congratulations to her and husband Chris.FORMER All Saints star Nicole Appleton has given birth to her second child, a girl called Skipper, at the age of .“After hiding my pregnancy for the last nine months – which was so dficult and keeping her a secret from all my friends – I can finally announce our incredible news!” she wrote on Instagram.Fascinating. It’s one thing wearing a big coat out in public, but how do you hide a growing bump from “friends” Has Nicole, whose boyfriend is Stephen Haines, been in pre-emptive self-isolation for the past few months Or is it simply that her petite frame and enviably taut stomach muscles meant she just looked like the rest of us after a big meal Personally speaking, by month seven I looked like I had a medicine ball stuffed up my frock.STORMZY reportedly ripped up his travel plans after meeting Victoria’s Secret model Yasmine Aisha Khala Holmgren backstage at a gig in Stockholm.The pair are said to have holed up in a hotel room for two days where, according to a friend of the grime star, they wanted to spend “quality time” together.That’s one way of putting it.A NEW biography about former Commons Speaker John Bercow claims that he didn’t speak to a female aide for the entirety of a nine hour flight – because he was furious that his toothpaste had been confiscated at airport security.Quite what it had to do with her is anyone’s guess.But one imagines she was grateful for the prolonged period of peace.HANNAH SMITH, a -year-old mum of one, has been handed a suspended sentence after admitting the crime of harbouring a criminal.Her boyfriend, violent robber Luke Harvey, scaled the wall of HMP Sudbury in Derbyshire, where Hannah was waiting to drive him to Skegness for a weekend away.They were later pulled over by police and Harvey, , had ten months added to the -year sentence he received in .Leicester Crown Court was told that the couple had now split up.Presumably, actually spending time together proved too much.HERE is yet another photograph of the singer and actress Jenner Lopez looking sensational at . Sigh.Apparently, this latest photo-shoot, which highlights her enviably toned and tanned legs in a tuxedo-style leotard, is to promote her new footwear line.Is she wearing shoes We hadn’t noticed. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. Why our 'exceptional' new Chancellor is the bright person for the job
title: rishi sunak coronavirus economy meltdown
story: Some have already lost their jobs. Others must now give theirs up to look after their kids, with schools closing.It may be hard for politicians to grasp, but many ordinary people have no savings to tide them over.They are broke NOW. They need to feed themselves and their families NOW.Not at the weekend. Not next week.Even those not yet made redundant by this global economic collapse are petried about how bad this could get.The pub industry alone says hundreds of thousands of jobs will be lost imminently without immediate help.Other governments have stepped in. Why has ours been so slow Devising a new system to get tens of billions in lost wages into the right hands is complex. We get that.We also think the “universal income” idea is an ill-considered and permanently ruinous fix.But promises, and a temporary ban on evicting renters, won’t quell the fear.This virus is not the fault of the workers, nor the Government whose draconian restrictions are sound.But with the economy in total meltdown, only the Government now can get Britain paid.Do it today, Rishi.CLOSING schools was grimly inevitable but right. It always seemed odd to keep them open while telling everyone to stay home.The Government must fulfil its pledge to ensure kids on free school meals are fully funded to get fed.We pay tribute to the NHS staff, delivery drivers and social carers whose often low-paid work is so essential that their children WILL still be looked after in school.And our hearts go out to the teenagers whose GCSEs and A-levels will be postponed indefinitely.This is an unprecedented nightmare, blighting their childhoods.We can only help each other endure it.IMAGINE the evil of using a deadly ­pandemic to spread fake news furthering your political or commercial agenda.It should no longer shock us after the Salisbury poisonings.But Kremlin trolls are sowing panic online to undermine the West’s Covid- strategies.Let’s remember that, next time our leaders have to make nice with Putin at the G.Meanwhile, conspiracy cranks say hand sanitiser causes cancer — and charlatans claim their “yoghurt suppositories” or vitamin pills “cure” the virus.Where do they do this with near impunity  That’s right . . .On Facebook, which talks such a good game about policing its site — but is always found wanting.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus key workers children school
story: KEY workers whose children will be allowed back to school as they play a crucial role in Britains fight against coronavirus have been named by the Government. The working heroes include nurses, police officers and delivery drivers and their children will be exempt from the decision to close classrooms from Monday to stop the spread of the deadly bug.A No source confirmed to The Sun Online only one parent needs to be eligible for kids to be allowed back to class.The Government today named nine sectors critical to the COVID- response - Health and social care Education and childcare Key public services Local and national government Food and necessary goods Public safety and national security Transport and Utilities, communication and financial services.Families have been urged not to leave their children with grandparents aged over  in order to protect the elderly, who are most at risk from the deadly bug.Education Secretary Gavin Williamson said: We still need to have our critical infrastructure that continues to work and .Click here to see the full list of workers.It comes as:The Government has today laid out a detailed list of people defined as key workers.This includes doctors, nurses, midwives, paramedics, social workers and care workers.It also means other frontline staff such as support staff, producers and distributers of medicines and medical equipment.Includes nursery and teaching staff, social workers and special education professionals.Includes courts staff, religious staff, undertakers and people in charities delivering key frontline services.Journalists and broadcasters are also on the list because of the crucial service they provide in keeping the public informed.Government staff who are essential to the response to COVID- or delivering essential public services such as the payment of benefits.Those involved in food production, processing, distribution, sale and delivery as well as those essential to the provision of other key goods Includes police and support staff, Ministry of Defence staff and the armed forces.Firefighters, National Crime Agency staff and border security, prison and probation workers are also includedThose who keep air, water, road and rail services operating.Staff needed for essential financial services, IT and data which are needed to continue during the coronavirus response.Infrastructure workers who maintain oil, gas, electricity and water supplies are also included.This also features key staff in the civil nuclear, chemicals, telecommunications, postal services and delivery, payments providers and waste disposal sectors.Workers are advised to check with their employerthey are included.The announcement as Boris Johnson spells out his warplan to beat coronavirus.Yesterday, Britains death toll rose to  with a total of , confirmed cases.Boris told the nation he is absolutely confident that we can send coronavirus packing in this country and the tide can be turned within three months.He said: Im conscious as the days have gone by that people will want to know how long were expecting them to keep it up.I think, looking at it all, that we can turn the tide within the next  weeks and Im absolutely confident that we can send coronavirus packing in this country.But onlywe all take the steps that weve outlined, that is vital, thats how were going title: coronavirus covid 19 super rich testing kit private jets leo mckinstry
story: JUMPING the queue, expensive testing kits and escaping to distant sanctuaries in private jets - this isnt just isolation, this is elite, super-rich isolation.As the coronavirus pandemic sweeps across the world, some celebrities, millionaires, and members of the business class seem to believe that their wealth can be used as a form of vaccination while the rest of us face the deadly risk of infection.Such behaviour is entirely against the public spirit of the moment. This is a time for unity and for respecting others, especially the most vulnerable.As the Queen put it yesterday in her admirable statement: “I am reminded that our nation’s history has been forged by people and communities coming together to work as one, concentrating our combined efforts with a focus on the common goal.”As the emergency deepens, abuse of privilege should play no part in our national response.But that is exactly what is now happening, as is graphically demonstrated by the saga of private Covid- tests kits.One of the biggest problems the Government faces is the shortage of capacity for testing.To prevent the current system from being overwhelmed by demand, NHS policy is only to test people with a “high chance” of having the illness, such as those who have ed from high-risk countries or are displaying symptoms.Even doctors and nurses working in the front-line are not routinely tested.But to evade such official restrictions, a growing number of the rich and famous are forking out for private coronavirus kits, which can cost anything between £ and £.According to one report this week, more than , wealthy figures in Britain have ordered such kits.Dr Mark Ali, director of the Harley Street clinic, said: “We have private iniduals – some recognisable names there – and we are testing lords and ladies and even doctors and dentists who are worried about catching the disease.”It is the same story of privileged access in the US, where, just as in Britain, shortages of supplies mean that many health care workers and sick people are unable to get diagnoses.But some stars seek to bypass rules that limit tests to those most at risk.A huge controversy erupted this week at the news that eight top NBA basketball teams has been tested, making a mockery of the rationing.Bill de Blasio, the mayor of New York, spoke for much of the public when he said that “an entire NBA team should not get tested for Covid- while there are critically ill patients waiting to be tested. Tests should not be for the wealth, but for the sick.”On both sides of the Atlantic, this two-tiered approach is wrong on so many levels.It is a deep insult to healthcare workers. It is profoundly isive.And it does not lessen the burdens on the NHS here in Britain, as some apologists pretend.Those who test positive will still have to be treated in the health service, since the British private medical sector does not have the resources for this crisis.Selfish and irresponsible, the Covid-test queue jumpers are the equivalents of the supermarket stockpilers or the social distancing refuseniks who still insist on going down to the pub.During the Second World War, when the Blitz spirit was at its peak, there was fierce hostility to rich iniduals who tried to cheat on rationing regulations or avoid national service.The same contempt should now be shown to those who try to dodge the rules that promote fairness.But it is not just in testing where the narrow self-centredness of the rich can be found. They use their wealth to insulate themselves in other ways.Some are buying special private medical care, like intravenous infusions of vitamins and minerals to boost their immune system.Lansherhof, a private medical facility at the London Arts Club, reported this week an  per cent increase in enquires for its Immune Plus Support Infusion, which costs £.The rich are also using private jet travel to avoid the rest of the public as they conduct business or fly to remote havens.Inquiries for international flights by private jets are estimated to be up nine-fold since the outbreak began, while Hong Kong International Airport reported this week its busiest day for private jet activity.Nor do the rich have to endure the normal airport ordeal suffered by other passengers.A spokeswoman for Quintessentially, a concierge company for millionaires, said: “Members who are travelling commercially are choosing to book elite services at airports, not your typical first-class lounge.For example, private terminals where guests are greeted and given their own suite.Check-in, customs and security are all done privately and guests are taken to the doors of the aircraft.Members can request for the jetty to be cleared so they minimise the interactions with other passengers”.Most Brits have no choice over where they live in the midst of this crisis.But that is not true of the wealthy who can find sanctuary in one of their many properties or rent out an expensive rural bolt-hole.Some are now paying £,-a-month for a luxury base in the Cotswolds.Nor does self-isolation have to be the imprisoning experience that it is for ordinary citizens.The rich can bring in private chefs for their dinners, or expensive tutors for their children.The company Tutors International, which provides elite tuition services, says it has seen “a massive upswing in requests” since the outbreak began.The elite even have luxury face masks. The fashionable Airinum Urban Air Mask costs £ and claims to protect “against airborne particles as small as .mm.”But in this rarefied world, problems are faced by the elite that would never be considered by others.Wailing that she now has now chance to show off her expensive jewellery, one female financier in London says: “I’m just not sure when my next ball will be.”The experience of the affluent is in dramatic contrast to the misery faced by people at the other end of the scale.While the rich cocoon themselves, it is the wage-earners, the straitened households, the poor and the unemployed who are now in the eye of the storm.Our society is just beginning to realize the terrying consequences of this disaster, where the mounting death toll is matched by economic meltdown.Vast numbers of people – from hotel cleaners to airline cabin crew, from bar staff to retail assistants – are going to lose their jobs.The ranks of the five million self-employed will be decimated. Small businesses across the country will collapse.Food banks are already running short of supplies, while the plight of the homeless – who cannot isolate themselves on the streets – is desperate as shelters close.At worst, our prosperous civilisation could slide into a kind of modern feudal structure, with only the aristocracy at the top enjoying a decent standard of living.At a press conference in the White House on Wednesday, President Trump was asked whether “the well-connected go to the front of the line”.He replied philosophically: “You’d have to ask them that. Perhaps that’s been the story of le.”But it should not be that way, especially when mankind is facing one of its darkest hours.We should all be in this together.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: social distancing must be in place year coronavirus
story: BRITAIN must remain in lockdown for up to a year to prevent the NHS being overwhelmed, the Government’s doomsday research warns.Scientists have advised Boris Johnson that shutting schools and telling Brits to stay out of pubs and workplaces for only a few months is not enough to beat the coronavirus. They suggest alternating between severe and less strict measures, with the harshest curbs in place on and off but for a total of at least six months over this period.The advice is included in evidence considered by the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies, published online yesterday.Sir Patrick Vallance, the Government’s Chief Scientic Adviser, said the analysis had played a “considerable role” in shaping restrictions.One of the reports warns just isolating sick households and cocooning vulnerable groups is “very unlikely to prevent critical care facilities being overwhelmed”.And it adds: “It was agreed that a policy of alternating between periods of more and less strict social distancing measures could plausibly be effective at keeping the number of critical care cases within capacity.“These would need to be in place for at least most of a year.“Under such a policy, at least half of the year would be spent under the stricter social distancing measures.”Dr Jenny Harris, the deputy chief medical officer, issued the warning — but said it was important kids still exercise.Speaking alongside PM Boris Johnson, she said: “The basic strand running through these measures is social distancing. That applies to children just as it does to the rest of us.”She said it was fine for siblings or children in “household groups” to play together.Dr Harris added that team sports should be avoided by both children and adults.The stark warning was issued in a document from a Scientic Pandemic Influenza Group, dated this Monday.But just three days later, the PM said the UK could “turn the tide” on the outbreak within  weeks.The experts say restrictions could be imposed or lted to control the spread of the virus and may y in dferent UK countries and regions at dferent times.However, they warn there is a risk of a second wave of infections later in the yearthe Government enforces too many restrictions at once and then lts them later.They also say school closures alone will have little impact on the epidemic and hit poorest families hardest.It could delay the peak by up to three weeks and reduce cases and deaths by five per cent.However, they also argue classroom shutdowns would be “most effectivestarted as early as possible” — a revelation likely to anger critics questioning why they were not shut sooner like in other European nations.Isolating sick households is predicted to reduce the peak of the outbreak by a quarter and deaths and cases by ten per cent.But getting people to work from home and avoid pubs, restaurants and cinemas has the greatest potential impact — reducing the peak by up to  per cent and deaths by  per cent.Researchers found Brits were most likely to catch coronavirus in family gatherings. title: dog breeders joy after callie the bulldog gives birth to twenty puppies
story: Callie the bulldog was in labour for an exhausting three days as she gave birth to her huge litter.Breeder Amber Rees and her partner were thrilled at all the puppies and are doing their best to cope with all the new additions to their household.Amber, from Swindon, Wilts, have only just set up her new business, Blue Blood Empire for a particularly rare breeds of dogs - Alapaha blue blood bulldogs.While nine of Callies remarkable litter did not survive past their first week, the other eleven are thriving and are a great start for Amber and her business.She admitted looking after them was proving dficult.She told Wessex news: This could be a record litter for Swindon and they can be quite a handful.I think Callies handled this better than I have. Its been chaotic and crazy but quite fun.Amber said the adorable additions were heartwarming to have around.She said: Seeing all those puppies together has been really heartwarming and sweet but it does test your patience sometimes.We are so proud of Callie, shes done so well, all things considered.This was her first litter and it was tough to see her go through so much effort but shes been such a good mother.After a good rest, Callie is back on her feet and enjoying her huge litter of puppies.Amber said: She was very tired for a few days but shes started wagging her tail again and is back to her funny, ditzy old self.At first we were a bit nervous because we were not sure how well she would look after the puppies but she responds whenever one of them makes a noise and is always on her guard immediatelyanyone comes near them.The puppies came as a huge surprise to Amber, who wasnt expecting anywhere near the amount of puppies to be born.When we first took her for a scan, the vet told us to expect six or at most eight puppies, but they just kept on coming. I was shocked but delighted.After the first , she slowed down a bit so the vet gave her an injection to help give her contractions and push the last six out.The nine that did not make it were born too prematurely and did not survive more than a few days.Amber added: It was a bit of a traumatic birth and Callies waters broke before some of them were ready to come out.The others are happy and healthy, fortunately, and weve stocked up on beds and dog food for them.Now we just need to think of  names to officially register each puppy.I thought about going with Disney princesses for the females but after calling one of them Ariel, I decided that it didnt really suit her.When a new owner buys them, they can rename them. Callie was originally called Gabana.

title: pubs london closed coronavirus
story: PUBS, restaurants, and other venues in London will be ordered to close over the coronavirus surge.Boris Johnson chaired an emergency meeting this morning as the Government tries to find ways to battle the outbreak.Gyms, leisure centres and cinemas all across the capital are facing closures, with Boris expected to make the announcement at todays pm press conference.Shops are not expected to be affected in the move, but could be struck down laterthe outbreak fails to slow down.It comes amid growing concerns that Brits are refusing to social distance, and continuing to pile into pubs and clubs after work.Pictures have shown boozed-up Brits spilling out of clubs and bars as they continue to ignore government advice.The pub-goers have been slammed on social media after cases of the title: brit in barcelona coronavirus lockdown shares supermarket pics
story: When lockdown was announced on Friday Victoria Mullen said the supermarket shelves were bare.People were struggling to get hold of essential items like pasta and toilet rolls but now they are realising there is no need to stockpile.“Seeing so much negativity and fear I wanted to try to share something to help the worry of going on lockdown,” Victoria told Birmingham Live.“We are on lockdown in Barcelona ... however, we are allowed out to the supermarket and to the pharmacy and, contrary to belief, you’re not holed up for the whole time, you can go out for essentials as long as you are straight back home.”“You’re allowed out to walk your dogs etc, just no social gathering at all. What you’re seeing on social media is causing fear and panic and making you bulk buy which is affecting the vulnerable and the supermarkets cannot keep up with the demand.“I took some photos today in the supermarket in a country that is on lockdown to show you what it looks like, you will not be without food.“Just to confirm on Friday when lockdown was announced our shelves were bare and we had no pasta or toilet roll just like you’re seeing.”Victoria, who is from Middlesbrough, added: This is five days in and we are stabilising as people have realised there is no need to bulk buy. Hoping this helps and you see the same.“Please try not to worry and try to give the shops a chance to catch up with the demand and give others a chance to get what they need.“Keep calm, carry on and be safe.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus bins no collections
story: FAMILIES have today been told to take their rubbish to the tip as bin collections will be cancelled during the coronavirus outbreak.Councils across the country have scaled back household bin collections and people have been told take their own waste to the dump rather than wait for lorries.It comes as:On Thursday, Cambridge City Council announced it would suspend all garden waste collections from Monday until May .The council said on its website: The suspension of green bin collections will allow crews to concentrate on emptying blue and black bins during the coming weeks.It will also assist with any future staff sickness or self-isolation issues.Some local councils have suspended waste collection services in a bid to stop the spread of Covid-, which has killed  people and infected , people in the UK.Other councils are also following suit, including Cheshire West and Chester, and Derby City Council, the latter of which has also suspended bulky waste collections.GO TO THE TIPDerby City Council said it predicts the coronavirus pandemic will also affect recycling and general waste collections in the coming weeks.Local authorities are asking residents who are self-isolating to place personal waste - such as used tissues and cleaning materials - into a plastic bag before disposing of it into a second bin bag.They are then encouraged to store it safely in their homes for  hours before placing it into a wheelie bin for collection.Hackney Council said this measure aimed to lower the risk of the virus being passed on.Meanwhile, Brighton and Hove Council is urging people with cars to take the rubbish of friends and neighbours who are unable to do so.The move has infuriated residents - especially the elderly - who have no means of disposing of rubbish.Eileen French, , said: “What are the elderly supposed to do “We have bins overflowing into the streets and no way of getting rid of it. I think it is disgraceful the council has made this announcement so soon into this crisis.“Coronavirus raises all sorts of public health concerns and the council seems to be abdicating responsibility.”Ellie Wood, from Brighton, said: “At times of stress it is up to the council to try and maintain basic services. Rubbish strewn across streets is a clear sign of civil breakdown.“The council has a responsibility to maintain collections not just from a health and hygiene position but also to reassure residents that there won’t be some total deterioration of services.”Another resident said: “This the exact moment they should be going the extra mile, for all of us, including themselves. If refuse starts piling up in the streets, other diseases will spread, put extra strain on the NHS.“The bin collectors will not escape these consequences either.”A spokesman for Brighton and Hove Council said: “We will be unable to catch up on missed work. If a collection is missed, residents’ next collection will take place on their next scheduled collection daypossible.“Residents can take any type of waste to the two Household Waste Recycling Centres . This can include taking friends and neighbours wastethey can’t get there by car.”A spokesman for the Local Government Association said: As councils prioritise protecting the vulnerable, there will be inevitable disruption to other important services, such as bin collections and street cleaning.Some councils are having to change their waste and recycling services as coronavirus impacts on their collection staff.Residents are encouraged to visit their council website for ongoing updates on bin collections.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus doctor photography competition scottish mountains
story: Dr Kenny Muir won the prestigious title with his stunning pictures taken in remote parts of Scotland.Dr Muir was labelled Scottish Photographer for the Year with his breathtaking photos.The stand-out picture was of Seilebost Gneiss, where he captured the Luskentyre estuary, framed by the snowy mountains of North Harris.He said: “I am shocked and delighted to have won this competition, particularly when surrounded by so many talented photographers.“Two of the winning images are part of a personal project to document the wilder side of Glen Affric, one of Scotland’s largest remnants of Caledonian Forest. I hope to highlight the importance of preserving and regenerating these areas of natural beauty.”His win comes as the confirmed cases of coronavirus continued to soar to , in the UK with  deaths.Dr Muirs portfolio featured images from Glen Affric and the Island of Harris.Dr Muir is currently fighting the outbreak of the deadly COVID- virus at Raigmore hospital in Inverness, Scotland.He said he would need to take a break from photography to focus all his efforts on keeping people alive and well.As a hospital doctor I will be taking a break from photography to focus on current events, but really appreciate receiving the award.His portfolio featured images from Glen Affric and the Island of Harris.Another standout shot was of one of the many small lochs deep within Glen Affric, capturing morning lighting hitting the native pinewoods after an evening of snow.The Scottish Landscape Photographer of the Year competition consists of a number of categories, including Landscape, Seascape, Urban, Monochrome, Four Seasons and Scottish Weather.Andrew Bulloch, from Edinburgh, won the Youth Category for the second year running, with his image of ‘The “Beast from the East” hits Edinburgh’.Andrew said: “The heavy snowstorms that hit the UK in March  were clearly visible as they swept across the city. I climbed to the summit of Arthur’s Seat to get the best viewpoint and had to get pulled out of a snowdrt on my way down.”Founder of the competition Stuart Low said in this tough times, he hoped the photos would give everyone some much needed joy.Stuart said: “In these dficult times ahead of us, we hope these stunning images will bring a little joy to everyone.”All the winning images will be showcased in a limited edition book that will be available from April .

title: seagulls in benidorm lockdown
story: A RAVENOUS colony of seagulls praying on an elderly shopper in coronavirus-stricken Spain have been captured on camera.In the attack, which looks like it’s been taken from the script of Alfred Hitchcock’s Hitchcock’s horror classic, The Birds, the gulls can be seen tormenting the elderly person who is carrying their shopping in Benidorm.Locals claimed online the aggressive birds have now taken to attacking people on brief trips for groceries in the ghost town resort.Their normal source of food is said to have vanished after bars and restaurants were shut and everyone was ordered to stay inside on Monday.Spain has become the fourth-hardest hit country in the world, after China, Italy which has now become the epicentre of the outbreak, and Iran.A total of , people have died in Spain after testing positive for coronavirus.British tourists holidaying in the country were this week urged to ‘leave now’, after the government said hotels would be on shutdown from next week.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Over the weekend Brits were spotted defying the country’s lockdown and taunting police in Benidorm at the weekend.A video which appeared on social media showed a group of around  people — some topless, others holding cans of beer —  boisterously chanting outside a block of flats as officers attempt to get them to go inside.Comments underneath the video state get them back to the UK and what unconsciousness, irresponsibility and stupidity.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: vat suspended for three months
story: The Chancellor has relieved the pressure on firms by deferring the next quarter of VAT payments, worth more than £billion.A loan scheme to help cash-starved firms will also be extended to help companies through the economic storm.The governments intervention comes as the the UKs COVID- death toll hit .Appealing to the British people to pull together, Mr Sunak vowed to stand behind the UKs workforce and its employers as he unveiled the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme.The VAT holiday will give firms valuable breathing space as they fight to stay afloat during the epidemic, which has ripped across the world.Mr Sunak said: To help businesses keep people in work, Im deferring the next quarter of VAT payments.That means no business will pay VAT from now to mid June. Youll have until the end of the financial year to repay those bills.Thats a direct injection of over £bn of cash to businesses equivalent to . per cent of GDP.A loan scheme to help businesses will also now be interest free for a year, an extension of six months.The Coronavirus Business Interruption Loan Scheme will be available from Monday.Mr Sunak assured businesses we in government are doing everything we can to protect you as he rolled out  the Treasurys battle plan.He added: We want to look back on this time and remember how in the face of a generation-defining moment, we undertook a collective national effort and we stood together.Its on all of us.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.The government will also cover up to  per cent of workers wages up to £, a month through grant funding - worth as much as £, a year per employee.It would cover earnings backdated to March  and be open for at least three months with no limit on the amount of funding available.Mr Sunak described the bumper package he unveiled today as unprecedented in the history of the British state.In support of businesses and workers Mr Sunak wrote a blank cheque by also announcing:The Government is also pledging nearly £ billion for renters through increasing housing benefit and Universal Credit.Todays announcement comes on the back of a £ billion coronavirus loan scheme for businesses to access, which was announced by Mr Sunak on Tuesday.Business chiefs have given the Chancellors new measures a massive thumbs up today.Adam Marshall, director general of the British Chambers of Commerce, said: The chancellor has given businesses desperately needed breathing room at this critical moment.The deferral of VAT payments keeps money in the pockets of businesses so that they can pay their people and suppliers, and the commitment to cover wages of those unable to work will allow firms to retain jobsthey are forced to reduce their operations.The Prime Minister also revealed that pubs restaurants and leisure centres across the whole of Britain will shut as soon as possible tonight amid the spiralling coronavirus crisis.Speaking alongside Mr Sunak, Boris Johnson made the unprecedented announcement ordering all venues to shut their doors as the government tries to battle the outbreak. Pubs restaurants and leisure centres across the whole of Britain will shut as soon as possible tonight amid the spiralling coronavirus crisis.Speaking alongside Mr Sunak, Boris Johnson made the unprecedented announcement this evening ordering all venues to shut their doors as the Government tries to battle the outbreak.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.

title: prince harry meghan markle coronavirus lockdown text
story: Some .million vulnerable Brits have been ordered to cut themselves off to save themselves from the deadly outbreak.And the Duke and Duchess of Sussex begged their .million Instagram followers to let those in isolation know youre thinking of them.Coronavirus has so far killed  Brits, with , cases recorded in the UK.Most of those deaths have been in the oldest generation, those over , who are now more vulnerable than ever, but who had been facing a loneliness crisis that was bad enough before coronavirus.In their post, the Sussexes said: Our emotional well-being is challenged every day whether we realise it or not, but our lives are usually filled with distractions.Now with constantly changing COVID coverage, we are all adjusting to this new normal and the feelings that come with it.But here’s the good thing : Yes, there is isolation and physical distancing, but there doesn’t have to be loneliness.The couple recommend online courses and resources for counselling and therapy, along with ways we can all get involved.The post concludes: Reach out to your friends, family and colleagues.Phone calls and video conferencing are such a great way to feel more connected - askthey’re okay, tell them how you’refeeling, and use this time to really listen for the answer.If there is someone you know and are worried about, your text may be the thing that saves their le.Prince Harry has previously been very open about his own struggles with mental health and the dficulties he faced in the wake of his mothers death.As of today, pubs, bars, gyms, shops and clubs are all closing, cutting everyone off from most face to face interaction. I say this: you will not face this alone.”To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Harry and Meghans message comes as the couple ed to Canada this month after completing their final engagements as Royals.The Sussexes had dramatically announced they were quitting the Firm in January - with their last day settled for March  after negotiations with the Queen.And it has been claimed the couple and baby Archie, who is ten months, are now self-isolating in their luxury North American home.With everything going on, it’s a lot to take in. Many of us may feel confused. Or alone, or anxious or scared...and in isolation, some of us may just feel bored, or that you don’t know what to do with yourself without your normal routine. story: BINGO halls, massage parlours, bookies and gyms are among the businesses that will close their doors tonight as Britains coronavirus lockdown ramps up.Boris Johnson also ordered pubs, restaurants and leisure centres across the UK to close as soon as possible amid the spiralling COVID- crisis.The PM  made the unprecedented announcement this evening ordering all venues to shut their doors as the Government tries to battle the outbreak.Cinemas, theatres and galleries will also close in a desperate bid to save British lives as the UK death toll rose to  today.The full list of sectors affected is:The measures will remain in place for  days to strengthen social distancing and protect Brits from the deadly virus.Restaurants will still be allowed to do takeaways, while supermarkets are unlikely to be affected at this stage.Mr Johnson said: Clearly, there are licencing arrangements which will make it relatively simple to do should that be necessary.We will enforce it strictly, but in reality everybody can see the imperative of doing what is necessary, of protecting our NHS and saving lives.The government lockdown will be reviewed after the two-week shutdown ends.Pleading with Brits not to go out tonight, Mr Johnson added: These are places where people come together and indeed the whole purpose is to bring people together but today for now we need to keep people apart.And I want to stress that we will review the situation each month, to seewe can relax any of these measures.And listening to what I have just said, some people may of course be tempted to go out tonight. But please don’t.You may think that you are invincible but there is no guarantee that you will get mild symptoms and you can still be a carrier of the disease and pass it on to others.At the historic press conference, Chancellor Rishi Sunak also unveiled tax cuts and wage boosts in a bid to relieve income lost due to coronavirus.Mr Sunak revealed a package to pay wages of up to  per cent for people who are not working but kept on payroll.He said: I have a responsibility to make sure that we protect, as far as possible, peoples jobs and incomes.Today I can announce that in the first time of our history, the Government is going to step in and help pay peoples wages.When this is over - and it will be over - we want to look back on this moment and remember the small acts of kindness done by us and to us.We want to remember how we thought first of others and acted with decency...its on all of us.In support of businesses and workers he also announced:Yesterday ministers revealed emergency legislation which would give them the powers to shut down any establishments which could be considered to host gatherings - from clubs and pubs to restaurants and bars.It will allow ministers to close anywhere which could reasonably be argued was spreading coronavirus.The bill will let the government restrict or prohibit events and gatherings during the pandemic in any place, vehicle, train, vessel or aircraft, any movable structure and any offshore installation and, where necessary, to close premises.The pub ban comes amid growing concerns that Brits are refusing to social distance, and continuing to pile into pubs and clubs after work.Pictures have shown boozed-up Brits spilling out of clubs and bars as they continue to ignore government advice.The Government earlier insisted that London would not be going on lockdown, and there were no plans to stop people leaving their homes.They also stressed that Brits will also not be confined to their homes as the UK death toll hit .It comes as:Matt Hancock had earlier pleaded with the public to follow Government advice, insisting it was the only way to get it dealt with in -weeks.He explained: “If people follow the advice, we can get through this quicker.“Evenyou dont think you are personally at risk because you are younger, which by the way isnt true, this affects everybody,you dont follow the advice we are going to have to keep these measures in place for longer.“For everyones sake I think everyone needs to pull together and listen to the experts.”Sadiq Khan had earlier told Londoners to “stop travelling and avoid social interaction”.The news is a blow to Wetherspoons owner Tim Martin, who had insisted his pubs would be open for the duration.Despite the pandemic, he said: I think that once you shut them down its very dficult.Supermarkets are very, very crowded. Pubs are much less crowded. Theres hardly been any transmission of the virus within pubs and I think its over the top to shut them.Thats a commercial view but also a common sense view.Piers Morgan hit back at his comments, labelling them insane stupidity.

title: british scientists coronavirus vaccine
story: BRITISH scientists are leading the fight against coronavirus by developing vaccines and trialling drugs that may boost recovery.Oxford University researchers are planning a human trial of what is expected to be the UK’s first coronavirus vaccine next month.It will start animal trials next week at Public Health England’s Porton Down lab, near Salisbury, Wilts.The vaccine could be available by summer — much quicker than the  to -month wait for a jab that Sir Patrick Vallance, the UK’s chief scientic adviser, has predicted.The Oxford vaccine, known as ChAdOx, is one of five frontrunner vaccines in development around the world.Researcher Prof Adrian Hill said: “The more vaccine we can provide sooner, the better.”UK biotech firm Synairgen will trial its experimental lung drug SNG on Covid- patients from Monday.The inhaled treatment has been developed for chronic- obstructive pulmonary disorder , a severe lung disease. To receive our Covid- newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.It is designed to boost the patient’s immune system to help them fight off the virus and could be widely available by the end of the year.US firms are also trialling potential treatments, while some Chinese doctors are trying malaria drug chloroquine.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: french snatch lorries 130000 coronavirus masks
story: The cargo was being urgently ferried in a major boost for over-stretched UK medics battling coronavirus.But French border guards impounded the trucks after realising what was on board.They were acting on President Emmanuel Macron’s pledge to “requisition” all masks for his country’s fight.The seizure came just  hours after another British-bound vehicle carrying thousands of bottles of hand sanitiser was also held up on the other side of the Channel.UK officials were quickly alerted to both incidents.And after tense, top-level talks, the lorries were allowed to leave with all supplies on board.A government source said: “On Tuesday night, French authorities stopped the hand sanitiser and confiscated the lot. “On Wednesday night, it was lorries full of FFP face masks to protect staff.”To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.But a Whitehall source added: “Both incidents were dealt with relatively quickly.“There is a clear understanding between countries that only a united approach will tackle the public health emergency all countries face.“It appears to have been a misunderstanding, we’re confident it won’t happen again.”President Macron had promised on Twitter on March  that the French “will requisition all stocks and the production of masks”.Former Tory party leader Iain Duncan Smith said: “This shows you all you need to know about European co-operation.“Europe is in lockdown and each nation has been left to their own devices.”Paracetamol exports from Britain have been banned as ministers move to protect vital stocks.Officials have halted firms from shipping  key drugs abroad, including adrenalin, insulin and common painkillers.Health Minister Lord Bethell said: “NHS staff are going above and beyond to provide world-class care to patients and we are supporting them in every way we can.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: britain has more than enough loo roll for people to stop panic buying according to andrex manufacturer
story: Kimberly-Clark — which makes Kleenex and Andrex — assured The Sun that plants across the UK are working flat out to meet increased demand.Toilet paper has been flying off the shelves in chaotic scenes as worried shoppers stock up amid the coronavirus epidemic.Kimberly-Clark usually makes .million rolls a day at plants in Northfleet, Kent, and Barrow, Cumbria — and has now boosted production.A spokesman said: “There is just no need to panic buy. We make one billion loo rolls a year that’s enough to stretch easily around the country.“The trucks are going out replenishing stock all the time but the problem is that as soon as it’s going out people are buying it straight away and they just don’t need to.’’Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
